name: Expert Plus
language: Microsoft Extended Basic (MSX Basic V1.0) + Demonstration software
keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard with numeric keypad, 5 function keys and 4 arrow keys
cpu: MSX Engine T7937A (single chip gathering Z80, Video, I/O and audio functions)
rom: 32 KB BASIC/BIOS ( MSX BASIC V1.0) + ?? KB (demonstration software)
graphics: Mode 2 : 256 x 192 with 16 colors (Hires mode)Mode 3 : 64 x 48 with 16 colors (Multi colour mode)32 sprites
sound: General Instruments AY-3-8910 Programmable Sound Generator3 channels, 8 octaves
ports: 2 controller ports, 2 cardridge slots, Tape interface (1200/2400 bauds), RGB video output, Composite video output, TV RF output, Centronics interface, Audio output
description:
The Gradiente Expert Plus is a Brazilian MSX 1 computer. It is composed of two parts: the main unit and the keyboard. Gradiente is a Brazilian consumer electronic products company. It is not suprising as the unit's design looks like a HI-FI system... Along with the Hot-Bit, the Experts were the only MSX systems available in Brazil. The first model (Expert XP-800) was in fact a clone of the National CF-3000.

It is a quite complete MSX 1 computer with two cartridge slots placed on the front panel and a numeric keypad. The system is powered by the MSX engine, a kind of super-chipset, gathering the CPU, video, input / output and audio functions.

The Expert can be used as videotext terminal (Telesp) with the TM-1 cartridge which includes a 1200 baud Modem, a serial interface and a phone socket...

The Expert Plus follows the Expert XP-800 (released in 1985) and the Expert GPC-1 (1986), which are quite similar. The Expert Plus was released (1989) at the same time as the Expert DD Plus which is the same system with a built-in floppy disk drive (720 KB).

Marcelo Ortega from Brazil adds:

The Expert Plus and DD Plus had a big incompatibility problem, that actually was not Gradiente's fault. Both machines used the MSX engine SMT chip, that made things easier to Gradiente assembly these computers, solving the bad contact problems of the socketed chips used in the previous Experts, and replacing three chips by one, but the MSX engine chip mapped the RAM to a internal secondary slot.

This was OK for the MSX standarts, but most brazilian software was written to run in Experts and Hotbits without secondary slots, and this resulted in many crashes.
 
The Expert users were also waiting for a MSX2 machine when the Plus was launched, and along with the common crashes, this made these machines not so popular.

The DDPlus uses a internal disk controller board that was quite similar to the external cartridge interfaces sold then. It also uses 16Kb for MSX DOS, resulting in 48Kb of ROM. The drive is very good (mine still works flawless !) but it was painfully slow.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> EXPERT DD PLUS</strong></font><br><blockquote>This model has a built-in floppy disk drive.</blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982) - PAGE 3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the box arts are completely different from the final ones (see software section)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666"> Our Peripheral Expansion System gives you plug-in cards for memory expansion, P-Code capabilities, a disk drive controler and the RS-232 interface. You can also add a modem, speech synthetiser, disk drive and matrix printer...<br><br> ... TI BASIC is built into the computer, but it can also handle TI Extended BASIC, UCSD Pascal, TI LOGO, TMS-9900 Assembly language and TI PILOT ... </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUTER NOTES</strong></font><br><blockquote>This fanzine - one of the first of the microcomputers era - was published by the Altair User Group<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR TECHNOLOGIES CREATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The conbination of Victor Business Products and Sirius Systems Technology Inc. creates a new company designed to meet the most demanding needs of the modern business office...<br> ... The result is Victor Technologies Inc., a company idally suited to dramatically impact today's international computer marketplace.<br><br> The Chairman of the board of the new Victor Technologies in Fred Sullivan, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Kiddle, Inc., a diversified $3 billion company. The financial support of this giant conglomerate will help focus Victor's goal of becoming one of the three leading computer companies in the world.<br> President and Chief Executive Officer of the new company is Chuck Peddle. Acknowledged as the "father" of the personal computer concept, Peddle introduced this useful and very affordable third generation micro-computer in the European market with startling results..</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Under all pictures of the promotional guide, you can read : "all screenshots are real and have not been retouched". <br><br> Really?</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> For years, people have been trying to build a better Apple II.<br> It finally happened.<br> Meet the Apple IIe, an impressive new version of a most impressive machine.<br> The 'e' means enhanced. Which means a bundle of new features...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>''It's time''<br> ''ATMOS from Oric : the definitive computer''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (FEB. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Educatel advert for their correspondance courses using the Microlab system.</blockquote>

emulator.name: openMSX - The MSX emulator that aims for perfection.
emulator.description: This new MSX emulator can reproduce, among many other MSX, MSX2and  MSX2+ machines, both Panasonic Turbo-R models. Be sure to get the catapult frontend and the system roms from FUNET.
